information:
As of mid-May 2025, New York Yankees player Aaron Judge's batting average was reported at various points between .402 and .423. On May 17, after a 2-for-4 game, his average reached .414, though a subsequent 0-for-5 game lowered it. By May 18, Judge had accumulated 15 home runs and 41 RBI for the season, leading the league in several offensive categories. An analysis by MLB.com noted that achieving a .414 batting average with over 15 home runs within a team's first 44 games is a rare historical feat, with parallels to seasons by Mickey Mantle in 1956 and Manny Ramirez in 2001.

According to a list of National League batting leaders published on May 18, 2025, Freddie Freeman of the Los Angeles Dodgers was leading with a .375 average. Other top hitters included Will Smith (Los Angeles Dodgers) at .336, Brendan Donovan (St. Louis Cardinals) at .330, and Manny Machado (San Diego Padres) at .323. In the American League, David Alonso of the New York Mets had a team-high batting average of .308 as of May 17. In Triple-A, Chicago Cubs prospect Matt Shaw was reported to be hitting .400 over his last eight games.

The last Major League Baseball player to finish a season with a batting average of .400 or higher was Ted Williams, who hit .406 in 1941. One analysis noted that modern players face challenges in reaching this mark, such as higher strikeout rates; early in the 2025 season, Aaron Judge had 31 strikeouts, whereas Williams had only 27 in his entire 1941 season. Another factor is Batting Average on Balls In Play (BABIP). The major league-wide BABIP in 2025 is .288, compared to .300 in 1930. In 2000, Ichiro Suzuki recorded a .387 batting average but was limited to 105 games due to an injury.

forecast.time_left_until_outcome_known: Approximately 13 days. The outcome will be known on June 1, 2025.
forecast.status_quo_outcome: Yes. As of mid-May 2025, New York Yankees player Aaron Judge has a batting average above .400.
forecast.no_outcome_scenario: Aaron Judge's current hot streak ends, and his batting average regresses to below .400 over the final two weeks of May. No other player manages to reach the .400 mark by the deadline.
forecast.yes_outcome_scenario: Aaron Judge continues his strong hitting performance, batting well enough over the next two weeks to keep his season average at or above .400 when checked on June 1, 2025.
forecast.rationale:
My forecast is heavily influenced by the current status quo. As of May 18, 2025, Aaron Judge's batting average is .414, which satisfies the 'Yes' condition. With only about 13 days until the June 1 resolution date, the core of the question is whether he can maintain this for a relatively short period. My analysis suggests this is quite likely. Assuming Judge plays in approximately 12 more games with 48 at-bats, he would need to hit roughly .354 over that span to keep his overall average above .400. While a .354 average is elite, it is a plausible performance for a player of Judge's caliber who is in the midst of a historically significant hot streak.

My probability is not higher because of the inherent volatility of batting averages. A short slump, such as going 2-for-15 over three or four games, could quickly drop his average below the .400 threshold. The modern game, with its higher strikeout rates and defensive shifts, makes maintaining such a high average challenging even for two weeks. An injury is also a low-probability but high-impact risk.

My probability is not lower because Judge has a significant buffer. A simple regression to his career mean performance would likely not be enough to pull his average below .400 in this short timeframe; it would require a distinct cold streak. The required performance level of hitting ~.350 for two weeks is difficult but far from impossible for a top player. Furthermore, there is a small secondary possibility that another player, such as Freddie Freeman (currently at .375), could get exceptionally hot and also cross the .400 mark, providing another path to a 'Yes' outcome.

I would lower my forecast if Judge has two or three consecutive poor games in the coming week. Conversely, I would raise my forecast if he continues his torrid pace for another few games, further increasing his buffer.
